{"title":"page 29","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"29
Sec. 12. He shall give his name or number to
all persons who may inquire.
Sec. 13. He must never use his club, except in
the most urgent case of self-defence.
Sec. 14. Policemen must not walk together, or
talk with each other when they meet on the confines of their beats, unless it be to coirynunicate
information appertaining to the department—such
communication to be as brief as possible.
Sec. 15. It shall be the duty of policemen on
night duty to walk their beats continually, and if
convicted of any neglect of duty, such as being
found asleep, having any unnecessary conversation with any individual, being off their beat, or
in any manner not complying with the instructions
or orders given them by their officers, they shall
be liable to be suspended or discharged.
Sec. 16. The Policeman on duty during the
night shall, after gun-fire, arrest all slaves who
may not have a legal pass from their masters, mistresses or employers, and convey them to the Police Station Houses of their respective districts. *
